content.div:
Dwayne Johnson replaces Brendan Fraser in this family-friendly sequel that is short on sense and high on campy entertainment. Johnson and returning cast member Josh Hutcherson journey to a magical island. Michael Caine and Vanessa Hudgens are along for the ride -- and when the island starts to sink, the group must struggle to devise an escape plan.

Starring: Dwayne Johnson, Michael Caine, Vanessa Hudgens, and Josh Hutcherson

Rating: Three stars out of five

It's hard to dislike The Rock. Both intentionally and unintentionally hilarious, wrestler Dwayne Johnson always seems to end up the only redeeming factor in otherwise horrendous films. It's no exception in the case of Journey 2: The Mysterious Island, where the mere fact that he's replacing Brendan Fraser from the original Journey film, circa 2008, is funny in itself.

In this belated sequel, he steps onto the scene about three minutes in, when his stepson Sean (Josh Hutcherson, the lone returning cast member) gets in trouble with the cops. Why? Oh, nothing major, he just broke into a satellite tracking facility to receive a coded message sent from his estranged grandfather on a make-believe island and then crashed his dirt bike into the neighbours' pool while trying to escape.

Because this is a children's movie and children have barely functioning attention spans, director Brad Peyton skips over the boring "you're grounded" scenes in what feels like a mad dash to explain the film's title. Hank (Johnson) asks Sean about this secret message, glances at the piece of paper, and immediately decodes it -- all of the two-syllable words stand for dots, and the one-syllable words are dashes. Yep, Grandpa has cleverly turned Morse code into something much longer and more unwieldy.

In seconds, it's deduced that the islands written about in Robert Louis Stevenson's Treasure Island, Jules Verne's Mysterious Island and Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels are actually the same island, and if you rip out the maps in each book and overlap them in just the right way, they create a new map for how to get there, and by the way, it's off the coast of Palau and here are two plane tickets for us!

Soon enough, the cast expands to four, as we're introduced to Gabato (Luis Guzman), a scrappy helicopter tour operator, and his daughter Kailani (Vanessa Hudgens), whose svelte figure clad in Daisy Dukes and a one-size-too-small tank top appears in the frame before her face does. Together, they fly directly into the eye of a hurricane and crash into the mysterious island. Of course, not one of them suffers so much as a bruise; even the ukulele is completely intact.

This is important, because we are soon to be treated to one of The Rock's shining moments, in which he picks up the tiny instrument and serenades us with a cheery rendition of "What a Wonderful World." If this sounds absurd, wait until he starts cuddling a mini-elephant (warning: major cute overload) or teaching Sean how to flirt with girls by pumping his pectoral muscles one at a time. (The scene actually drags on for minutes on end, until The Rock is flicking berries off his chest and into Guzmen's mouth.)

By now, younger audiences will probably be giggling, while their grown-up counterparts wonder what the heck is going on here. Prepare to keep wondering; it's not going to become any clearer. For a while, the foursome just mosey around the island, an esthetic ripoff of Avatar's Pandora, until they bump into Sean's grandfather (Michael Caine -- seriously), who leads them to a volcano that erupts liquid gold, then to the Lost City of Atlantis. Yes, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.

The problem is, it's sinking and they have to escape in the next 48 hours. How? By going underwater (sans scuba gear, of course) and finding Captain Nemo's old Nautilus, which will (obviously) still be in perfect working condition. Actually, its batteries are dead, but that's hardly an issue when The Rock can simply harpoon a gigantic electric eel and conduct its voltage directly to the ship's engine. Duh.

Although most Vernians would surely roll their eyes at all of this, there's humour to be found in the sheer outlandishness of the plot, and Peyton's directorial audacity. Barely anything makes sense, but it hardly matters.

There's little reason to gripe when you're treated to Michael Caine flying a giant bee, Luis Guzman freaking out at a lizard before uttering the line, "I hope she doesn't like food with poop in its pants," as The Rock just stands there and pumps his pecs to save the day.
